title: UK banks face £5bn lawsuit over forex claims
text:
Tip : Use comma (,) to separate multiple quotes. Learn more... 
Sat, Aug 22, 2015, 20:26 BST - UK Markets closed UK banks face £5bn lawsuit over forex claims By Tim Wallace | Telegraph – 1 hour 30 minutes ago 2.65 -0.07 
Firms from pension funds to international manufacturers are investigating the possibility of making claims for damages, accusing banks of manipulating exchange rates to rip them off 
UK banks could be facing additional legal bills of as much as £5bn as private investors look to launch legal action relating to allegations of foreign exchange rate manipulation, according to senior lawyers who have run successful lawsuits in the US and hope to do the same in London. 
Individual companies could be planning to lodge claims for tens of millions of pounds each, and David Scott, managing partner at Scott and Scott, one of the law firms which has headed the legal action in the US , said he has been inundated with queries from potential claimants in Europe. * British firms and pension funds facing a foreign exchange time-bomb * Bank switching service still not good enough, says Tesco (Xetra: 852647 - news ) chief “We’ve been speaking with a tremendous number of institutional clients, many of whom are in the UK. They want us to help them pursue claims,” said Mr Scott . Those include pension funds, hedge funds and non-financial companies, who trade foreign exchange to support their overseas units or to bring back profits from abroad. 
Half a dozen banks in the UK have been fined by regulators for attempting to manipulate forex benchmarks, the price of currencies at a fixed point in the day against which many trades are carried out. 
But Mr Scott said his cases in the US have uncovered evidence of spread manipulation through the whole trading day, and accuses banks of ripping off the buyer and seller of currencies to increase the bank’s own profit margin. 
He plans to lodge cases in the Autumn to seek compensation for clients who will say they were harmed by banks forming a cartel in the currency markets and breaking competition laws. 
So far in the US, 12 cases into this area have been settled with banks paying more than $2bn to date. Another seven banks have not settled the claims, and the claimants, who include pension funds and hedge funds, hope to win at least another $2bn. 
As currency markets are twice as large in the UK, the lawyers believe the claims for damages could come in twice as high at $8bn, or £5bn. That compares with regulatory fines for Libor and forex abuse of £2.2bn in the UK. 
Scott and Scott is setting up an office in London and is hiring in a new partner to run the British operation. 
The lawyers are also looking at using the new Consumer Rights Act to lodge claims on behalf of large numbers of clients. 
“The act is new and is not yet in effect, so there are many open questions on its implementation and how it is going to actually work, but the idea is that it would provide people or entities who do not have a large enough claim, to seek redress through collective proceedings,” Mr Scott said.
